channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Moscow Journal: A Moscow of Dancing Feet, Under an Iron Fist
item.description: The Russian capital is looking ever more like an elegant European capital, but its political life is marching steadily in the opposite direction.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Valeri Nistratov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dancing on a recent summer’s day in Gorky Park, Moscow.

item.title: 4 Rescued in Mali Hotel Attack
item.description: Mali’s special forces rescued four United Nations employees, who hid in the hotel after Islamic extremists killed nine people, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Final Hearing for Reporter Held in Iran Is Scheduled for Monday
item.description: The trial of Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post correspondent held in Tehran for over a year, “may now finally be nearing its end,” The Post’s executive editor said.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: On 70th Anniversary of Nagasaki Bombing, Atomic Debate Yields Little Consensus
item.description: On the anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima, The Times asked readers to debate Truman’s decision. As Japanese commemorate the Nagasaki anniversary, we review that debate.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: On Aug. 9, 1945, the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Nagasaki, the second such attack on Japan in three days.

item.title: Poor E.U. Migrants Test Limits of Swedish Tolerance
item.description: Attacks are on the rise, as the arrival of newcomers from within the European Union itself adds to the pressures from a rising tide of refugees.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Moa Karlberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elena Stanescu and Mariana Ion, begging in central Stockholm. Last month, someone threw gasoline on them. Mariana, set ablaze, had to run to a fountain.

item.title: India Warns TV Stations Over Criticism of Hanging
item.description: Three networks were accused of violating rules by showing interviews that criticized the execution of Yakub Memon for the 1993 Mumbai bombings.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW

item.title: Manuel Contreras, Chilean Spy Chief, Dies at 86
item.description: Gen. Contreras, Chile’s intelligence chief during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, was serving 526 years of multiple prison terms for human rights violations.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:description: Gen. Manuel Contreras in 2004. Under the Pinochet regime, he headed the spy agency that tortured and killed dissidents.

item.title: Congolese See No End to President’s Final Term
item.description: President Joseph Kabila is carving the country’s 11 provinces into 26, which many Congolese see as a ploy to delay the coming presidential election and allow Mr. Kabila to “slide” into a third term.
item.dc:creator: SARAH M. KAZADI and REBECCA SESNY
item.media:description: President Joseph Kabila at the United Nations in 2006.

item.title: Opinion: Is India Selling Out Its Tigers?
item.description: The Modi government is diluting environmental protections.
item.dc:creator: SHARON GUYNUP

item.title: In Handling Barrage of Attacks, Afghan Forces Show Training Is Paying Off
item.description: Officials noted that in none of the three bombings on Friday, scattered across Kabul, did the insurgents manage to breach their targets’ inner defenses.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men cleared rubble on Friday from the site of a truck bombing, the first of three major attacks on the Afghan capital that killed at least 65 people.

item.title: 4 Years After Fukushima Nuclear Calamity, Japanese Divided on Whether to Return
item.description: Thousands have joined lawsuits or organized groups to oppose the plan by the government to repopulate areas hit by the Fukushima Daiichi meltdowns.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenji Hasegawa, left, a former dairy farmer and an evacuee, used a survey meter to measure radiation levels in the neighborhood where he lived before the nuclear disaster.

item.title: 29 U.S. Scientists Praise Iran Nuclear Deal in Letter to Obama
item.description: The letter from some of the world’s most knowledgeable experts in nuclear weapons and arms control called the agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program innovative and stringent.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Father of Palestinian Toddler Killed in West Bank Arson Attack Dies in Hospital
item.description: Saad Dawabsheh was severely burned in the July 31 firebombing that killed his 18-month-old son, Ali, for which Jewish extremists have been blamed.
item.dc:creator: RAMI NAZZAL and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A Palestinian man mourned next to the body of Ali Dawabsheh, an 18-month-old boy who died in a July 31 arson attack in the West Bank. The boy's father, Saad Dawabsheh, 32, died on Saturday from wounds sustained in the attack.

item.title: Typhoon Soudelor Kills 6 in Taiwan and Leaves Millions Without Power
item.description: The storm had registered as the strongest of 2015 days earlier, but it had weakened by the time it made landfall in Taiwan early Saturday.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Damage from Typhoon Soudelor in Taipei, Taiwan, on Saturday. The storm weakened as it crossed the island and headed toward China.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Greek Mythology
item.description: As read by Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Chinese Human Rights Lawyer Is Unexpectedly Freed a Day After Being Detained
item.description: The lawyer, Yu Wensheng, one of dozens of legal professionals who have recently been detained, said Saturday he was stunned that the police had let him go.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Yu Wensheng demonstrating how death row prisoners are handcuffed. Although he was handcuffed during his time in custody this week, Mr. Yu said his interrogators were comparatively civil.

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: 2 Punished for Insulting King
item.description: Thai military courts sentenced two people to long prison terms on charges of insulting the monarchy, lawyers and a legal monitoring group said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Nagasaki, the Forgotten City
item.description: The survivors, long overshadowed by those of Hiroshima, demand to be heard.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: SUSAN SOUTHARD

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Militants Seize Hostages at a Hotel
item.description: Jihadists stormed a hotel where United Nations staff members were staying, seizing hostages and killing at least six people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Dozens of Syrian Christians Missing From Town Attacked by ISIS
item.description: Contact with the Christians was lost after the jihadists attacked the isolated oasis town of Qariyatain in Homs Province and routed the Syrian Army.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD
